questions.text: Defect at the level of the optic chiasma will result in which of the following visual field defects? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

Lesion at the level of the optic chiasma causes bitemporal hemianopia.

 

Nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Hence, the lesion at this level produces bitemporal hemianopia.

 

 

Common causes of the central chiasmal lesion are as follows:

 

  • Suprasellar aneurysms
  • Tumors of the pituitary gland
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Suprasellar meningioma
  • Glioma of the third ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central Scotoma - This refers to a loss of vision in the central visual field and is typically associated with diseases affecting the macula or the optic nerve, not lesions at the chiasm.

 

Option B. Bilateral Hemianopia - This would involve a loss of vision in the same half of the visual field of each eye (either left or right), which generally occurs with lesions affecting the optic tract or occipital lobe, not the chiasm.

 

Option C. Binasal Hemianopia - This visual field defect involves loss of vision in the nasal halves (the sides closest to the nose) of both eyes, which is uncommon and would more likely result from unusual patterns of optic nerve damage rather than a central chiasmal lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitemporal hemianopia is a classic sign of a lesion at the optic chiasm, often caused by conditions like pituitary tumors or chiasmal compression. This key symptom helps in diagnosing issues that may require urgent intervention to prevent further neurological damage.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with distant visual acuity of 6/18, which improved on pin-hole testing. He gives history of not needing glasses for near vision now. On ocular examination findings as shown in image were seen. Patient has which of the following refractory error. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Index Myopia

 

Given the patient's age and the description of the symptoms, the most likely refractive error in this case is Index Myopia. This occurs when nuclear sclerosis starts in the crystalline lens, resulting in change in the density and hence the refractive index of the lens. This causes light rays to focus in front of the retina, leading to blurred distant vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axial Myopia: Axial myopia is a common form of myopia and is usually a stable condition that doesn't suddenly appear in old age.

 

Option B. Curvatural Myopia: This form of myopia is due to an increased curvature of the cornea or lens, which makes the eye's focusing power too strong. This also results in the focal point being in front of the retina, causing distant objects to be blurred. Like axial myopia, curvatural myopia is generally present from a younger age and does not develop suddenly in seniors.

 

Option C. Positional Myopia: This type of myopia can occur due to the displacement of the lens within the eye, which can sometimes happen with a subluxated lens. Positional myopia is not a common form of myopia and would not typically be associated with the symptom of improved near vision without the need for glasses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phenomenon of "second sight" in older adults is often associated with the development of nuclear sclerotic cataracts, which can cause a change in the refractive index of the lens, leading to index myopia. An important clinical sign is improvement in near vision in a previously hypermetropic (or presbyopic) individual, along with a decrease in distance vision that improves with pinhole testing. It's essential to recognize these signs and symptoms for the correct diagnosis and management of cataracts.

choices.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology
IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
DC Cardioversion is required in all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on ECG, which confirms the diagnosis. Each of the provided options needs to be evaluated for accuracy.

 

IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control. This is the correct statement. IV Digoxin is used for rate control in AF, particularly in patients with heart failure.

 

If the patient is stable and not in acute heart failure, beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology: This statement is incorrect. Atrial fibrillation can occur in morphologically normal hearts. Studies indicate that 15-35% of AF cases can be seen in individuals with structurally normal hearts, although it is more common in those with conditions such as heart failure or left atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. DC Cardioversion is required in all cases: This statement is incorrect. DC cardioversion is reserved for unstable patients or for rhythm control in selected chronic cases. It is not required for all AF cases.

 

Option D. Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a pulse deficit (difference between heart rate and pulse rate) can suggest AF, it is not a reliable diagnostic criterion as it can be observed in other conditions such as frequent ventricular premature contractions, cardiac tamponade, and severe heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Only Myasthenia gravis, among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an injection (Anti-ChE medication).

 

In myasthenia gravis, there is unilateral myogenic ptosis where, after a short rest, the symptoms recover rapidly.

 

A quick test in the office can be to ask the patient to look up and hold that position, and then observe if there is fatiguability of the levator muscle such that the upper eyelids start to drift downwards while the patient is looking up. The definitive diagnosis is made through various clinical, pharmacological and serologic tests.

 

Diagnostic Tests

 

1. Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test:

 

Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. This test is only useful in patients with objective, measurable findings on physical exam, like ptosis or a tropia. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post administration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes.

 

2. Ice Test:

 

This is also a simple diagnostic test that can be done in the clinic. It is highly sensitive and specific for MG. The ice test is useful for ptosis. An ice pack is applied to the affected upper eyelid for 2-5 minutes. A positive test is the improvement of ptosis by > 2mm or more. This transient improvement in ptosis is due to the cold decreasing the acetylcholinesterase break-down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th nerve palsy: This condition primarily causes abduction deficit (inability to move the eye laterally), which would not explain the ptosis nor improve with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option C. 3rd nerve palsy: Though it can cause ptosis and eye movement abnormalities, symptoms are due to mechanical dysfunctions or nerve damage and do not improve quickly with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option D. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (pupil constriction), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), but does not involve hypotropia or improve dramatically with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Note:

 

The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography

 

The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of angle-closure glaucoma visits her psychiatrist for follow-up. She has been feeling increasingly overwhelmed and tearful, struggling with severe depression, poor sleep, and a lack of interest in her usual activities. Her glaucoma is managed with regular ophthalmology visits and medication, but she remains concerned about how her eye condition might affect her mental health treatment. She previously tried an SSRI, which she stopped due to side effects, and is now seeking an alternative antidepressant that will not interfere with her eye condition. During the consultation, the psychiatrist discusses several medication options. Considering her history of angle-closure glaucoma, which medication should the psychiatrist avoid prescribing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Amitriptyline

 

Explanation:

 

Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), is contraindicated in patients with angle-closure glaucoma due to its significant anticholinergic properties. TCAs block muscarinic receptors, which can decrease the outflow of aqueous humor in the eye, leading to increased intraocular pressure. This can precipitate an acute glaucoma attack, particularly in patients with angle-closure glaucoma, who are already at risk due to impaired aqueous humor drainage. Therefore, amitriptyline should be avoided in this patient population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sertraline: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) with minimal anticholinergic effects, making it generally safe for patients with glaucoma. It does not significantly impact intraocular pressure and is a better choice for managing depression in this patient.

 

Option B. Bupropion: Bupropion is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) that lacks significant anticholinergic activity, making it a suitable option for patients with glaucoma. It does not adversely affect intraocular pressure and is often considered safe in these patients.

 

Option D. Mirtazapine: Mirtazapine is an antidepressant that acts primarily on noradrenergic and serotonergic pathways with minimal anticholinergic activity. It is considered safe for patients with glaucoma and does not significantly affect intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, antidepressants with anticholinergic properties, such as tricyclic antidepressants, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and worsen the condition. Safer alternatives include SSRIs, SNRIs, and NDRIs, which have minimal or no effect on aqueous humor dynamics.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of penetrating injury to the eye. A diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was confirmed. Which of the following will be seen? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Panuveitis

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis.
  • Usually occurs after penetrative trauma or intraocular surgery.
  • Both eyes develop panuveitis: the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye).
  • Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk.
  • The most accepted theory is the allergic theory which postulates that the uveal pigment acts as an allergen and excites plastic uveitis in the sound eye.
  • Usual time of onset of sympathetic ophthalmitis – 4-8 weeks after injury.
  • Earliest symptoms in uninjured eye:
    • Difficulty in near vision (Due to loss of accommodation)
    •  Photophobia
  • Earliest sign in uninjured eye: Retrolental flare.
  • Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis. These are small, yellow white spots scattered throughout the fundus. These consist of epithelioid cells and are present between retinal pigmented epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.
  • Best time for enucleation (not evisceration) of an injured eye in order to prevent sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye- within 15 days.

 

   

 

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease (VKH) and sympathetic ophthalmia (SO) are bilateral, autoimmune granulomatous intraocular inflammatory conditions with nearly identical findings on ophthalmic exam. Both can reveal serous retinal detachments, optic disc edema, vitritis, and Dalen-Fuchs nodules, but they differ in key facets such as a history of penetrating ocular injury in SO and greater systemic associations in VKH. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute anterior uveitis: Acute anterior uveitis involves inflammation limited to the anterior part of the uvea (iris and ciliary body) and does not typically follow the pattern seen in sympathetic ophthalmitis, which affects the entire uveal tract.

 

Option B. Pars planitis: Pars planitis is a form of intermediate uveitis that primarily affects the peripheral retina and pars plana. It does not encompass the entire uveal tract as in panuveitis.

 

Option D. Chronic anterior uveitis: Chronic anterior uveitis is a long-standing inflammation of the anterior uvea, typically affecting only the iris and ciliary body, not the entire uveal tract as seen in panuveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous panuveitis that occurs after penetrating eye injuries or intraocular surgeries, affecting both the injured and uninjured eyes. It involves inflammation of the entire uveal tract and is characterized by features such as Dalen-Fuch's nodules and retrolental flare in the uninjured eye.

questions.text: Which sequence of dyes is employed for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

The optimal sequence of dyes for ocular surface examination and dry eye staining from the provided choices is as follows: Fluorescein → Lisssamine green → Rose Bengal

 

Fluorescein stain – it is an orange colored dye → stains the defect. Under cobalt blue light, the defect appears green.

 

Rose Bengal stain – stains the dead cells. It causes stinging, so, not very popular, and so applied the last.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended sequence of application—starting with fluorescein, followed by lissamine green, and ending with Rose Bengal—minimizes discomfort and interference between the dyes. Since Rose Bengal can be irritating, it is applied last, after the assessment with the less irritating dyes has been completed.

questions.text: Identify the marked layer of the retina: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inner plexiform layer

 

The inner plexiform layer is marked in the above histological image of the retina.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inner plexiform layer of the retina is a crucial site for synaptic activity among various retinal cells, playing a key role in the preprocessing of visual information before it is sent to the brain. Recognizing this layer and understanding its function are important for comprehending the overall neural circuitry of the retina.

questions.text: In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), which of the following findings would be atypical for a classification of 'very severe’? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neovascularization of disc

 

  • In evaluating a patient with nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR), it is important to understand the typical and atypical findings associated with the disease severity:

 

This is considered an atypical finding for NPDR and is generally associated with proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR). NVD indicates a more severe and advanced stage where new blood vessels grow on the optic disc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous Bleeding: In NPDR, more common findings are microaneurysms or dot hemorrhages.

 

Option C. Retinal Hemorrhages: Common in NPDR, especially as the severity increases. These hemorrhages are often small and scattered throughout the retina.

 

Option D. Microaneurysm: A hallmark and typically one of the earliest signs of NPDR. These are small, round, red spots seen on fundoscopic examination caused by capillary dilatation.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When examining a patient with diabetic retinopathy, finding neovascularization would necessitate reclassification to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which requires different management strategies including possible laser therapy or anti-VEGF injections to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right superior rectus

 

  • The clinical scenario described is due to right superior rectus palsy.
  • The three-step test, also called the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, can help diagnose which muscle is paralyzed in acquired hypertropia. It involves using the cover-uncover test and Maddox rod to measure deviation in different head positions.
  • The three-step test can also diagnose inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy, but it's not reliable for multiple paretic muscles or restrictive strabismus.
  • In patients with inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist, the three-step test can distinguish between true or simulated superior rectus palsy.

 

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

 

Step 1. Which eye is hypotropic?

 

The eye hypotropic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

 

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

 

Step 2. Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

 

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

 

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

 

  • Left superior oblique
  • Right superior rectus

 

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

 

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis typically leads to hypertropia and excyclotorsion, not hypotropia.

 

Option C. Right inferior oblique: Incorrect, as paralysis would not result in the described pattern of hypotropia.

 

Option D. Left inferior oblique: Incorrect, since paralysis here does not explain the increase in hypotropia with right head tilt and right gaze.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three-step test is a vital diagnostic tool in strabismus evaluations to identify which extraocular muscle is paretic based on the changes in eye position with head tilt and gaze direction. In this scenario, the findings align with a right superior rectus muscle palsy, consistent with its role in elevating the right eye especially during right gaze and head tilt to the right.

questions.text: What is the treatment of ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fasanella servat operation

 

  • The affected muscle in Horner’s syndrome is Muller's muscle, a sympathetic muscle present in the eyelid responsible for upper eyelid retraction during sympathetic stimulation. 
  • In Fasanella servat surgery, the muller’s muscle is shortened and strengthened. 
    In the other two options, levator resection and frontalis sling surgery, Muller's muscle remains intact. 
  • Thus, if asked specifically for Horner’s syndrome, even if the grade of ptosis is not mentioned, Fasanella servat operation would be the better choice to answer.
  • Here the examiner is testing your knowledge about the pathogenesis of Horner’s syndrome and the involvement of Muller's muscle. 
  • Fasanella servat operation is done for mild ptosis (< 2 mm) caused by Horner's syndrome.

 

 

Horner's syndrome is a oculosympathetic syndrome characterized by a specific set of symptoms that typically occur on one side of the face and include:

 

  1. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs because the sympathetic nerves that control the Muller’s muscle, a modification of Levator Palpebrae Superioris, involved in elevation of the eyelid are affected.
  2. Miosis:  Dissenervation of the dilator papillae (supplied by the sympathetic system) leads to miosis.
  3. Anhidrosis: This refers to a decreased ability to sweat on the affected side of the face.
  4. Pseudo-enophthalmos
  5. Hyperemia – due to disenervation of vasomotor fibers.

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Levator resection: Used for moderate to severe ptosis, not typically indicated for the mild ptosis seen in Horner's syndrome.

 

Option B. Frontalis sling operation: Reserved for severe ptosis with poor or no levator function, which is not typical in Horner's syndrome where levator function is usually preserved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Fasanella-Servat operation is the appropriate surgical treatment for mild ptosis caused by Horner's syndrome, characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to sympathetic nerve disruption.

questions.text: The device shown in the figure is used for indirect ophthalmoscopy. What is the power of the lens that should be used with it to visualize the retina? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. +20 D

 

Explanation:


For indirect ophthalmoscopy, a +20 D lens is commonly used. This lens provides a magnification of about 3x, allowing a wide view of the retina and its structures. The power of the eye is approximately +60 D, and using a +20 D lens is optimal for indirect visualization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. -58 D - A negative lens is not used for this purpose as it would not provide the required magnification and visualization.

 

Option C. +60 D - A lens of this power would provide too high a magnification and too narrow a field of view for effective indirect ophthalmoscopy.

 

Option D. +90 D - This lens is typically used for other types of examination and would provide excessive magnification and a very narrow field of view.

 

Educational Objective:


A +20 D lens is ideal for indirect ophthalmoscopy, providing a suitable magnification and wide field of view for examining the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following triad is seen after an acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vogt's triad

 

  • Vogt's triad is seen after an acute attack of primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.
  • Glaukomflecken is used to describe an anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity due to necrosis of lens cortical fibers.
  • The mid-dilated pupil is attributed to sphincter atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Virchow triad is used to describe the abnormalities that result in thrombosis. It includes endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability of the blood.

 

Option C. Hutchinson triad is used to describe manifestations of congenital syphilis. It includes interstitial keratitis, Hutchinson teeth, and eighth nerve deafness. Hutchinson teeth are screw-driver or peg shaped small incisors.

 

Option D. Gaucher's triad is not a named triad. Hypertonia, strabismus, and stridor usually point to a diagnosis of type 2 Gaucher's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vogt's triad in a patient with a history of acute primary angle-closure glaucoma can aid in rapid diagnosis and management of this potentially vision-threatening condition. It underscores the importance of timely intervention to preserve ocular health and prevent irreversible complications.

questions.text: What is the center for vertical gaze? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal

 

Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal is the center for vertical gaze.

 

There are "centers" that control conjugate eye movements. The supranuclear centers are in the cerebral cortex.

 

  • The frontal cortex has an area that controls quick fixational eye movements to the opposite side.
  • The occipital cortex has an area that controls slow pursuit eye movements to the ipsilateral or same side.
  • Both supranuclear areas send impulses to the brainstem and to the centers that control conjugate eye movements.
  • The centers controlling eye movements in the brainstem are the final common pathway conveying impulses for movement in a particular direction.
  • The center controlling horizontal conjugate movements is the pontine paramedian reticular formation (PPRF), and it controls conjugate horizontal movement to the ipsilateral side.
  • An area controlling vertical movements lies just above the two-third nerve nuclei and is involved in the early development of pinealoma.
  • The center for convergence (Perlia nucleus) is associated with the third nerve nucleus and lies in the region of the Edinger-Westphal complex and an area coordinating divergence possibly exists.

 

 

  • In contrast to horizontal gaze, which is generated by unilateral aggregates of cerebral and pontine neurons, vertical eye movements, with few exceptions, are under bilateral control of the cerebral cortex and upper brainstem.
  • The groups of nerve cells and fibers that govern upward and downward gaze, as well as torsional saccades, are situated in the pretectal areas of the midbrain and involve three integrated structures-
    1. The riMLF (rostral interstitial nucleus of the MLF).
    2. The INC (interstitial nucleus of Cajal)
    3. The nucleus and fibers of the posterior commissure (PC)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pontine Paramedian Reticular Formation: Primarily responsible for horizontal gaze movements, particularly conjugate gaze to the ipsilateral side.

 

Option B. Raphe Nucleus: Involved in serotonin production and has a role in sleep and mood regulation, not directly involved in vertical gaze.

 

Option D. Nucleus of Perlia: Often associated with convergence but its exact role and existence are somewhat controversial and less defined in literature compared to well-defined structures like the INC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rostral Interstitial Nucleus of Cajal (INC) is the central control site for vertical gaze movements in the brainstem, playing a critical role in coordinating upward and downward eye movements.

questions.text: What event takes place when the retina is exposed to light? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperpolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release

 

The retina responds to light by initiating a process called phototransduction, which converts light energy into an electrical signal. This process involves the activation of rods and cones, which are the photoreceptor cells in the retina.

 

In the dark, the cGMP gated channels in the photoreceptor cells are open, allowing a steady release of neurotransmitters such as glutamate. However, when light falls on the retina, a series of biochemical reactions occur, leading to the conversion of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal. This process activates transducin, which is a G protein-coupled receptor with phosphodiesterase activity, resulting in the breakdown of cGMP. As a result of the decrease in cGMP levels, sodium channels close, causing hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell.

 

The hyperpolarization leads to a decrease in glutamate release, which ultimately triggers the formation of an action potential. This process enables the transmission of visual information from the photoreceptor cells to the brain, allowing us to perceive and interpret visual images.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperpolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells leads to a decrease, not an increase, in neurotransmitter release.

 

Option C. Depolarization, decrease in neurotransmitter release: This is incorrect because light exposure causes hyperpolarization, not depolarization, of photoreceptor cells.

 

Option D. Depolarization, increase in neurotransmitter release: This is also incorrect as it suggests the opposite response of photoreceptors to light. Depolarization and increased neurotransmitter release occur in the absence of light (i.e., in the dark).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Light exposure results in the hyperpolarization of photoreceptor cells in the retina, leading to a decrease in the release of the neurotransmitter glutamate. This process is crucial for converting light signals into electrical signals that can be processed by the brain to form visual images.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

questions.text: Identify the condition: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oculomotor nerve palsy

 

The given image suggests a diagnosis of oculomotor nerve palsy because of the following features:

 

  • Left eye is deviating downwards and outwards.
  • Left eyelid is showing ptosis.
  • Left eye is unable to move upwards, downwards, or inwards towards the nose, indicating a lack of adduction, elevation, and depression.

 

Signs observed in a patient with oculomotor nerve palsy include:

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position (“down and out”) due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Normal abduction due to the intact lateral rectus.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial rectus palsy: Incorrect because. Medial rectus palsy specifically affects the ability of the eye to adduct (move inward toward the nose). If only the medial rectus were paretic, you would primarily observe limitation in horizontal inward movement of the affected eye without the associated ptosis, "down and out" positioning, or pupil involvement seen in the provided images. These broader symptoms indicate involvement of multiple muscles, which is characteristic of oculomotor nerve palsy, not isolated medial rectus palsy.

 

Option B. Trochlear nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) palsy affects the superior oblique muscle, which primarily results in problems with eye rotation and vertical gaze, especially when looking downward and inward. Patients often present with vertical diplopia (double vision), head tilt away from the side of the lesion to compensate for the misalignment, and no ptosis or pupillary involvement. The symptoms and the eye movement limitations shown in the images do not match those typically associated with trochlear nerve palsy.

 

Option C. Abducens nerve palsy: Incorrect because. Abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) palsy results in failure of the lateral rectus muscle, leading to an inability to abduct the eye (move outward). Patients with this condition will have the affected eye positioned inward (medially) due to unopposed action of the medial rectus. This condition would not cause the ptosis or the "down and out" appearance nor the wide range of motion impairments displayed in the images, such as the inability to move the eye upward or downward.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oculomotor nerve palsy significantly affects eye movement and eyelid function due to its role in innervating most of the extraocular muscles as well as lifting the eyelid. Diagnosis often involves a comprehensive evaluation of eye movement patterns, eyelid function, and pupil response, along with investigations to determine underlying causes. Treatment focuses on addressing the root cause and managing symptoms to protect eye function and quality of life.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stereopsis test

 

The test shown in the above image is Titmus stereotest, which is done to test for stereopsis (perception of depth).

 

  • Patients are shown a picture of a housefly for children and circular patterns for adults.
  • The picture is held about 16 inches in front of the patient's eyes.
  • Patients are asked to wear polarized glasses during the test.
  • Normal perception of depth will cause the housefly to appear as a 3D image above the plane.
  • Patients will attempt to pinch the wings of the housefly in the air, above the plane of the image, if perception of depth is normal.
  • Defective perception of depth will cause the image to appear as a normal 2D image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ocular deviation: This refers to misalignment of the eyes, typically tested with cover tests or Hirschberg test, not the Titmus stereotest.

 

Option C. Refractive errors: These are assessed with vision tests using an eye chart, not stereopsis tests.

 

Option D. Colour Blindness: This is assessed using color vision tests like the Ishihara test, not related to depth perception tests like the Titmus stereotest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Titmus stereotest evaluates stereopsis or depth perception, an essential aspect of binocular vision, allowing for the three-dimensional interpretation of the world necessary for various activities and indicating healthy, cooperative eye function.

questions.text: The most common ocular manifestation of COVID-19 is: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular conjunctivitis

 

  • COVID-19 can cause ocular manifestations due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which are potential target tissues for SARS-CoV-2.

 

COVID-19:

 

  • Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinal vein thrombosis: While COVID-19 can cause thrombotic complications, retinal vein thrombosis is not commonly reported as a primary ocular manifestation of COVID-19.

 

Option B. Viral keratouveitis: There is limited evidence to suggest that COVID-19 directly causes viral keratouveitis. This condition involves inflammation of the cornea and uvea and is more commonly associated with other viruses.

 

Option D. Pseudomembranous conjunctivitis: Pseudomembranes in the context of conjunctivitis are not true membranes but rather a buildup of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and mucus. They can adhere to the conjunctival tissue and may cause a gritty or painful sensation in the eye. Some common causes of pseudomembranous conjunctivitis include:
 

  1. Bacterial Infections: Bacterial conjunctivitis, particularly caused by certain strains of bacteria like Corynebacterium diphtheriae or Streptococcus pneumoniae, can lead to the formation of pseudomembranes.
  2. Viral Infections: In rare cases, certain viruses, such as adenoviruses, can cause pseudomembranous conjunctivitis.
  3. Allergic Reactions: Severe allergic conjunctivitis can lead to the development of pseudomembranes, although this is less common.

 

Treatment for pseudomembranous conjunctivitis typically involves addressing the underlying cause, which may include antibiotics for bacterial infections or antiviral medications for viral infections. In some cases, topical steroids may be prescribed to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19, highlighting the virus's ability to affect multiple body systems including the eyes. This underscores the importance of protective measures for healthcare providers, such as wearing masks and eye protection when examining patients suspected of having COVID-19.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman with a history of myopia corrected by LASIK surgery 15 years ago presents with progressively worsening vision. She has difficulty reading, driving, and recognizing faces. After evaluation, she is diagnosed with cataracts and  scheduled for surgery. The ophthalmologist discusses the challenges of calculating the correct intraocular lens (IOL) power due to her previous LASIK surgery and explains the need for specialized methods to achieve accurate results. Which formula would be most appropriate for calculating the IOL power in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Haigis-L

 

Explanation:

 

The Haigis-L formula is specifically designed for calculating IOL power in patients who have undergone corneal refractive surgeries such as LASIK for myopia. Standard IOL calculation methods often fail in these cases because the surgery alters corneal curvature, making conventional formulas inaccurate. The Haigis-L formula uses statistical data to determine IOL power based on the altered corneal properties of post-refractive surgery eyes without requiring historical data, which is often unavailable. This approach is particularly useful for eyes that have undergone procedures like LASIK, ensuring better refractive outcomes. Other formulas such as the double-K method, Masket, and modified Masket are also used but may require more detailed inputs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SRK/T
This formula is commonly used for standard cataract surgeries but does not adjust for altered corneal properties from previous refractive surgery, leading to potential errors in IOL power estimation.

 

Option C. Holladay I
Holladay I is a standard formula for cataract surgery but lacks the necessary adjustments for post-refractive surgery patients, resulting in less accurate outcomes.

 

Option D. Hoffer Q
The Hoffer Q formula is primarily designed for eyes with short axial lengths and is not adapted for use in patients with previous corneal refractive surgery, often leading to inaccuracies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of LASIK undergoing cataract surgery, specialized formulas like Haigis-L are recommended to accurately calculate IOL power due to altered corneal curvature. This ensures better visual outcomes by compensating for changes induced by previous refractive procedures.

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediately

 

Immediate dilated fundus examination is recommended for individuals diagnosed with type 2 diabetes, as early detection of diabetic retinopathy is crucial for preventing vision loss. Screening at diagnosis is essential because diabetic retinopathy can be asymptomatic in its early stages, yet still pose a risk of significant damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Before his 50th birthday: While this is within five years of diagnosis, immediate examination is preferred for immediate intervention and management.

 

Option C. After his 50th birthday: Delaying the examination could lead to unnoticed progression of diabetic retinopathy and potentially irreversible damage.

 

Option D. When he complains of decrease in vision: Waiting for symptoms such as decreased vision can result in delayed diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy, at which point some damage may be irreversible.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma? (INICET Nov 2020
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Marcus Gunn pupil  

 

  • Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage.
  • A defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye can cause a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test.
  • The Marcus Gunn pupil is observed when the flashlight is moved from the normal to the abnormal eye and the affected pupil dilates instead of remaining constricted.
  • Seen in optic neuritis.
  • Earliest indictor of optic nerve disease (Retrobulbar neuritis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adie tonic pupil is a Sluggishly reacting mid-dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due to postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

 

Option C. Argyll-Robertson pupils (AR pupils) are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation, which is a specific sign in neurosyphilis and is due to a lesion in the pretectal nucleus.

 

Option D. Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial mass lesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marcus Gunn pupil, or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage, and is identified using the swinging flashlight test.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of keratoconus? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haab's striae  

 

Haab’s striae are not a feature of Keratoconus. Haab's striae are seen in buphthalmos where the intraocular pressure is raised and the eyeball is enlarged as a whole. The enlarged cornea is associated with tears in Descemet's membrane called Haab's striae.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Munson's sign: Directly associated with keratoconus. It is observed when the patient looks down, causing the lower eyelid to bulge out due to the cone-shaped cornea.

 

Option C. Irregular Astigmatism: A hallmark of keratoconus, resulting from the irregular thinning and bulging of the cornea.

 

Option D. Scissoring Reflex: This is a characteristic finding in keratoconus observed during retinoscopy due to the irregular shape of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Following signs may be elicited in keratoconus –

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the clinic with a history of hyperglycemia and has had positive urine glucose tests on two separate occasions in the last six months. The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician is considering various medications to manage the patient's condition and prevent potential complications, including renal involvement. Which of the following drugs will not delay renal involvement? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

  • Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension. 
  • While effective at lowering blood pressure, it does not have specific renal protective effects and may not delay the progression of renal disease in diabetic patients. 
  • In fact, in some cases, thiazide diuretics can increase the risk of developing hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: SGLT2 inhibitors (e.g., canagliflozin, dapagliflozin) are a class of medications used to lower blood sugar in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by promoting glucose excretion through the urine. Importantly, SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Finerenone: It is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist that reduces inflammation and fibrosis in the kidneys. Clinical trials have demonstrated that finerenone can reduce the risk of kidney disease progression in patients with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs (e.g., losartan, valsartan) are another class of medications used to manage hypertension and heart failure. Like ACE inhibitors, ARBs have been shown to provide renal protection and delay the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing proteinuria and lowering intraglomerular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, while SGLT2 inhibitors, ACE inhibitors, and ARBs have renal protective properties and can help delay renal involvement in diabetic patients, hydrochlorothiazide does not have these specific protective effects and is the correct answer in this context.

questions.text: Rice water diarrhoea, intoxication is due to which ganglioside?(NEET PG  2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GM-1 ganglioside receptor.

 

Explanation:

 

Rice water diarrhea is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. The toxin produced by Vibrio cholerae is the cholera toxin.

 

The cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on the surface of intestinal epithelial cells. This binding leads to the activation of adenylate cyclase, increased levels of cyclic AMP (cAMP), and subsequent secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, resulting in the characteristic rice water diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GM-2 ganglioside receptor: GM-2 ganglioside is not related to cholera toxin binding. Instead, it is involved in diseases like Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease, where there is a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase, leading to the accumulation of GM-2 ganglioside.

 

Option C. GM-3 ganglioside receptor: GM-3 ganglioside is not involved in the mechanism of cholera toxin. It is a simpler ganglioside involved in different cellular processes but not specifically in the pathology of cholera.

 

Option D. GD-1a ganglioside receptor: GD-1a ganglioside is not associated with the cholera toxin. It has roles in neural cell function and development but does not play a part in the mechanism of action of cholera toxin.

 

Educational Objective:


Cholera toxin binds to the GM-1 ganglioside receptor on intestinal epithelial cells, causing the characteristic rice water diarrhea by increasing cyclic AMP levels and promoting water and electrolyte secretion into the intestinal lumen.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 202

choices.text: Anterior surface of the cornea
Posterior surface of the cornea
Anterior surface of the lens
Posterior surface of the lens

questions.text: Which part of the eye contributes the most to its refractive power? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Anterior surface of the cornea

 

Explanation:

 

The anterior surface of the cornea is the primary contributor to the eye's refractive power. The curvature and refractive index of this surface are responsible for about two-thirds of the eye's total refractive power.

 

The anterior surface of the cornea, which is approximately spherical with a typical radius of curvature of 8 mm, is responsible for around two-thirds of the eye's refractive power.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior surface of the cornea - This surface does not contribute as significantly to the refractive power as the anterior surface.

 

Option C. Anterior surface of the lens - While it does contribute to the eye's refractive power, it is not as significant as the anterior surface of the cornea.

 

Option D. Posterior surface of the lens - This surface also contributes to refractive power but to a lesser extent compared to the anterior surface of the cornea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior surface of the cornea is the most critical part of the eye for its refractive power, contributing about two-thirds of the total refractive power.

questions.text:
A woman diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome has undergone a renal biopsy. All of the following statement(s) is/are true except? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy.
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy.
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma.
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

After an open or needle biopsy, patient will be kept in a recovery or an observation unit for 24 hours to monitor for potential complications, including pain and bleeding.

 

Bleeding and hematoma are the common complication of kidney biopsy. Patient can complain of blood or dark red clots in urine.

 

Statement 1. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is diagnosed by biopsy for which a tissue sample is obtained by an invasive technique (percutaneous renal biopsy).

 

It's named "focal" because only some glomeruli are affected, and "segmental" because only parts of each glomerulus are affected, so biopsy is essential to catch it.

 

Statement 4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy: Renal venules are not affected in renal involvement in systemic amyloidosis. While a renal biopsy can confirm renal amyloid deposition, less invasive sites (like abdominal fat pad aspirate, rectal mucosa, or gingival biopsy) are often preferred first. Most commonly Abdominal fat pad biopsy is done.

 

Other Options

 

Statement 2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy: After a renal biopsy, the patient should indeed be observed for 24 hours to monitor for potential complications like pain and bleeding.

 

Statement 3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma: The presence of dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy is indicative of a hematoma, which is a common complication post-biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous renal biopsy is a key diagnostic tool for conditions like FSGS, and proper post-procedure monitoring is essential to manage potential complications.

questions.text: New drug application is filed after which phase of clinical trials?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 

 

It is after the phase 3 of clinical trials that the drug is finally released in the market after being approved by the CDSCO/FDA. Therefore, a New drug application is filed after phase 3 of clinical trials.

 

The phases of clinical trials are as follows: -


Phase 1 - Done in healthy individuals to assess the maximum tolerable dose, safety and pharmacokinetics of the drug.


Phase 2 - Done in a small number of patients to find out whether the drug actually works or not, in other words to know about the treatment efficacy.


Phase 3 – Done in a large number of patients to compare the new treatment with the current standard of care. It is introduced into the market after this phase.


Phase 4 - Post marketing surveillance to detect the rare or long-term adverse effects, can even result in the treatment being withdrawn from the market.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A New Drug Application (NDA) is filed after the successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials, where the drug's effectiveness and safety are confirmed in a larger patient population. This phase is critical for regulatory approval and subsequent market release of the drug.

questions.text: An individual with type 2 diabetes mellitus was prescribed a medication that lowered their HbA1C levels from 7.6 to 6.7. Subsequently, the person began experiencing discomfort characterized by itching in the vulvovaginal region. What is the probable medication that was initiated for this individual? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Canagliflozin

 

The patient complaining of itching in genital region after consuming a drug to lower down HbA1C levels is likely pointing to urogenital infection, which is a side effect associated with Canagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor).

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Glucose is freely filtered by glomerulus but the clearance of glucose in urine is negligible.
  • Because the reabsorption takes place in proximal tubule by sodium glucose transporter (SGLT-2)
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors stop the reabsorption of glucose in PT resulting in glucosuria.
  • Most common side effect of SGLT-2 Inhibitors is Urinary Tract infections (urosepsis) and genital Tract infections. (e.g., Fournier’s gangrene)
  • If gliflozins are taken by type 1 diabetes patients, it controls blood sugar level and makes it normal and then if the patients stop taking insulin, it will result in Ketoacidosis (as type 1 diabetes is characterized by complete deficiency of insulin)
  • SLGT-2 inhibitors provide cardiovascular benefits. These are approved for treatment of CHF.
  • Drugs are.
    • Canagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin
    • Empagliflozin
    • Ertugliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that primarily acts in the intestine to slow down the breakdown of complex carbohydrates. It is not usually associated with vulvovaginal itching.

 

Option C. Linagliptin: A DPP-4 inhibitor, Linagliptin is not typically associated with vulvovaginal itching or infections.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: This GLP-1 agonist is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal side effects rather than vulvovaginal itching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that lowers blood sugar by causing more glucose to be excreted in the urine. It is known for causing genitourinary infections, including vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can result in symptoms like itching and discomfort.

choices.text: 3 swab test

questions.text: What is the most useful test in vesicovaginal fistula? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula (VVF). It allows direct visualization of the bladder and can help identify the exact location, size, and number of fistulas. Additionally, cystoscopy can be used to assess the bladder for any associated injuries or other abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. 3 swab test: This test is used to identify the type of genitourinary fistula (vesicovaginal or ureterovaginal) but is not as specific as cystoscopy for visualizing the fistula directly.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic structures and help in the diagnosis of fistulas, it is not the first-line investigation. It is more useful in complex cases or when additional information is needed.

 

Option D. Cystometry: This test evaluates bladder filling and voiding problems and is not specific for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystoscopy is the most useful test for directly visualizing vesicovaginal fistulas, determining their size, location, and number, and assessing the bladder for any associated injuries.

 

Ref: Page no 417, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Match the following drugs in column A to their site of action in column B?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2


The correct match is as follows:

 

 

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts at the proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Torsemide is a loop diuretic that acts by inhibiting Na+-K+-2Cl channel at the thick ascending limb of the Loop of Henle.
  • Chlorthalidone, a thiazide-like diuretic, inhibits the Na-CI symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • Vasopressin, or ADH, is secreted by the posterior pituitary and mainly acts on the collecting duct, and increases the reabsorption of free water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide acts on the proximal convoluted tubule, Torsemide on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, Chlorothiazide on the distal convoluted tubule, and Vasopressin on the collecting duct.

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pre-gestational diabetes

 

Explanation

 

The image shows a condition known as mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia, which is a rare congenital deformity characterized by the fusion of the lower limbs. This condition is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes.
  • Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes typically occurs later in pregnancy and does not usually cause congenital anomalies, as organogenesis is largely complete by the time gestational diabetes is diagnosed.

 

Option C. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure during pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects, facial anomalies (such as cleft lip and palate), and cardiac anomalies, but not sirenomelia.

 

Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers reduce fetal renal perfusion, leading to conditions such as oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but they do not cause sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-gestational diabetes is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies, including mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia), characterized by the fusion of lower limbs.

 

Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Increases urine output
Increases mean arterial blood pressure

questions.text: A patient of septicemia was treated with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following best parameter is used to monitor the effect of therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increases mean arterial blood pressure

 

Norepinephrine/ Noradrenaline, is a vasopressor commonly used in the management of septic shock. It works primarily by stimulating α1 and α2 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic vascular resistance. It also stimulates β1 receptors, which increases cardiac output.

 

  • Increase in Mean Arterial Blood Pressure (MAP): The primary goal of using norepinephrine in septic shock is to improve perfusion by increasing MAP. Monitoring MAP is essential because it provides a direct measure of the pressure needed to ensure adequate blood flow to organs. An increase in MAP indicates improved perfusion and is a key indicator of the efficacy of norepinephrine therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradycardia: Bradycardia can occur as a reflex response to the increase in blood pressure caused by norepinephrine. However, it is not a primary parameter for monitoring the therapeutic effect of norepinephrine in septic shock.

 

Option B. Tachycardia: Tachycardia is not typically expected with norepinephrine therapy and can be a sign of other issues or a compensatory response. It is not a direct indicator of norepinephrine efficacy.

 

Option C. Increases urine output: While increased urine output is a good sign of improved renal perfusion and overall hemodynamic status, it is a secondary measure. The primary aim is to stabilize the patient's blood pressure, making MAP the more direct parameter to monitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noradrenaline acts on the α1, α2 and β1 receptors. It leads to an increase in the SBP, a rise in DBP and therefore a rise in MAP. This helps in improving the perfusion in patients suffering from septic shock. The rise in mean arterial pressure also causes reflex bradycardia but it is not a major contributor to the treatment of septic shock

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

choices.text: Age 6 months – 5 years
Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes
No need for long term antiepileptics

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about febrile seizure?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 54% recurrence

 

Febrile seizures are convulsions brought on by a fever in infants or small children. They are relatively common and typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. The main features of febrile seizures include:

 

  • Age 6 months – 5 years: This is the typical age range for febrile seizures, making this statement true.
  • Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes: Simple febrile seizures are brief, usually lasting less than 15 minutes. This statement is also true.
  • No need for long term antiepileptic: In the case of simple febrile seizures, long-term antiepileptic treatment is generally not necessary. This statement is true as well.

 

The statement "54% recurrence" is not true. The recurrence rate for febrile seizures is significantly lower. While there is a risk of recurrence, it is not as high as 54%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febrile seizures typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, last less than 15 minutes, and do not require long-term antiepileptic treatment. The recurrence rate is much lower than 54%.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a painless, progressively enlarging mass in the upper outer corner of her right eye that she first noticed six months ago. She denies any pain, redness, vision changes, or recent trauma. On examination, there is a firm, non-tender mass in the area of the lacrimal gland, causing mild downward and inward displacement of the eyeball. Extraocular movements are normal, and there are no signs of inflammation. Imaging reveals a well-circumscribed, lobulated mass involving the lacrimal gland. A biopsy is planned to establish the diagnosis.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland. It usually presents as a painless, slow-growing mass in the superotemporal orbit, often displacing the globe downward and medially. These tumors are well-circumscribed, lobulated, and arise from the glandular tissue of the lacrimal gland, exhibiting a mixture of epithelial and myoepithelial cells, hence the name "pleomorphic." Although typically benign, there is a risk of malignant transformation over time, making complete surgical removal important. Diagnosis is confirmed by imaging and biopsy, showing a well-defined encapsulated mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphangioma: Lymphangiomas are benign vascular lesions that can occur in the orbit but typically present with a diffuse, cystic mass that often appears infiltrative rather than well-circumscribed. They commonly cause intermittent proptosis and are associated with episodes of hemorrhage, unlike the presentation of pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Option B. Dacryops: Dacryops, or lacrimal gland duct cysts, present as cystic lesions of the lacrimal gland ducts and can cause painless swelling. However, they appear as fluid-filled cysts on imaging rather than solid, lobulated masses and are usually more anteriorly located near the lacrimal gland ducts.

 

Option D. Chronic dacryoadenitis: Chronic dacryoadenitis refers to long-standing inflammation of the lacrimal gland, often due to autoimmune or systemic inflammatory conditions. It usually presents with glandular enlargement but lacks the well-circumscribed, lobulated appearance typical of pleomorphic adenoma and is often associated with systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the lacrimal gland, presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass that may cause globe displacement. Imaging typically shows a well-defined, lobulated mass, and diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy. Surgical removal is necessary due to the risk of malignant transformation.

questions.text: Ceftriaxone 180 mg is required for a patient. You're using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml. Ceftriaxone 500 mg/5ml is contained in the vial. How many divisions will you fill in the 2 mL syringe to give 180 mg ceftriaxone? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 18

 

In a vial of Ceftriaxone, it is given than 500mg is there in 5ml.

 

Therefore 180 mg will be present in 1.8 ml.

 

In the 2ml syringe there are 10 divisions per ml.

 

Thus, to take 1.8ml, we need to fill 10*1.8 = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:


To administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

questions.text: A 22y female is overdue by 2 weeks. She visits the OPD with complaints of vaginal bleeding and abdominal pain on the right side. On Examination, her vitals are stable. Abdomen examination is unremarkable. A bimanual examination reveals a bulky, soft uterus with no tenderness and no adnexal mass. Mild bleeding +. Beta hCG is 1400 IU. An ultrasound reveals a trilaminar endometrium, and both the adnexa are normal. The next best step is?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Repeat serum beta HCG after 48h

 

Explanation:

 

  • Repeat serum beta hCG after 48h:
    • The clinical scenario suggests a pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), which could either be a failing intrauterine pregnancy or an ectopic pregnancy.
    • The best next step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours. A rise in beta hCG by at least 66% would suggest a viable intrauterine pregnancy, while a plateau or drop would indicate a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Diagnostic laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and is not the immediate next step in the management of a stable patient with PUL. It is reserved for cases where there is a high suspicion of ectopic pregnancy with unstable vital signs or inconclusive non-invasive tests.

 

Option C. Repeat USG after 3 days: Repeating the ultrasound after 3 days may not provide additional useful information if the initial ultrasound did not show an intrauterine pregnancy. Monitoring beta hCG levels first is more informative and guides the need for further imaging.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: Simply waiting without further evaluation could delay diagnosis and appropriate management, especially in the case of a potential ectopic pregnancy, which can be life-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of pregnancy of unknown location (PUL), the next best step is to repeat the serum beta hCG level after 48 hours to differentiate between a viable intrauterine pregnancy and a non-viable pregnancy, such as an ectopic pregnancy or a failing intrauterine pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: In the motor homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Precision of movements

 

Precision of movements has maximum representation in the motor homunculus.

 

In the sensory homunculus, the relative sizes of the cortical areas is proportional to the use of the part, the number of specialized sensory receptors and precision required by respective peripheral area of the body.

 

Some body parts like lips are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex followed by the face and thumb while the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low control and skilled movements: Incorrect, as areas requiring low control do not have extensive cortical representation.

 

Option B. More muscle fibres are present: Incorrect, as the size of representation in the motor homunculus is not based on the number of muscle fibers, but rather on the precision and complexity of movements.

 

Option D. Intensity of perception: Incorrect, as intensity of perception is related to sensory input and the sensory homunculus, not the motor homunculus.

 

Educational Objective:
