The motor homunculus has maximum representation for body parts requiring precision of movements, reflecting the complexity and intricacy needed for fine motor control.

questions.text: A patient cannot identify objects but she can see the color, texture, shape. What is the site of the lesion? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital area

 

 

The patient’s symptoms indicate a condition known as visual agnosia, where there is an inability to recognize objects despite having intact vision for color, texture, and shape. This suggests that the primary visual cortex (area 17) is functioning properly, but the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) are affected.

 

  • Occipital Area: The occipital lobe, specifically Brodmann areas 18 and 19, are responsible for the higher-order processing of visual information. Lesions in these areas can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot interpret or recognize visual stimuli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial parietal area: The medial parietal area is not primarily  involved in visual recognition.

 

Option B. Lateral parietal area: The lateral parietal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Option C. Infra temporal area: The infra temporal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions in the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) of the occipital lobe can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot identify objects.

questions.text: A 27-year-old accountant underwent parotidectomy following which she developed lower lip paralysis. This probably occurred because of an injury to which of the following structures? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mandibular branch of facial nerve

 

The mandibular branch of the facial nerve, also known as the marginal mandibular branch, supplies motor fibers to the muscles responsible for lower lip movement. During a parotidectomy, there is a risk of injuring the nearby facial nerve branches, including the mandibular branch. Damage to this branch can lead to lower lip paralysis or weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal branch of facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates the muscles of the forehead and is not related to the lower lip.

 

Option B. Cervical branch of facial nerve: The cervical branch of the facial nerve innervates certain neck muscles and is also not related to the lower lip.

 

Option C. Parotid duct: The parotid duct, also known as Stensen's duct, carries saliva from the parotid gland to the mouth. Injury to this duct could result in salivary leakage from wound (salivary fistula).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lower lip paralysis is a result of an injury to the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve.
  • During parotidectomy, the facial nerve may be at risk of injury since it passes through the parotid gland.
  • The branches of the facial nerve include the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical branches.

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.text: A first year surgery resident, on rotation at a hospital, is tasked with inserting an intercostal drainage tube in a 65-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) who was admitted with a severe exacerbation of their symptoms. The surgery resident has previously performed the procedure under supervision, but this is their first time doing it on their own. Which of the following steps is incorrect? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib

 

Explanation:

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube should be inserted along the upper border of the lower rib, not the lower border of the upper rib. This is to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle, which runs along the lower border of each rib (comprising the intercostal vein, artery, and nerve). Inserting the tube along the lower border of the upper rib increases the risk of injuring these critical structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube: The 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is a commonly selected site for the insertion of an ICD. This location is within the "triangle of safety," which is bounded by the lateral border of the pectoralis major anteriorly, the latissimus dorsi posteriorly, and the horizontal level of the nipple below. This area minimizes the risk of injuring important structures, including the long thoracic nerve and vessels.

 

Option C. Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury: Directing the tube posteriorly initially helps ensure that it enters the pleural space without injuring the lung. Once inside the pleural cavity, the direction of the tube may be adjusted based on the specific indication for the ICD, such as draining an effusion versus a pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Incised and digitally explored: After making a skin incision, blunt dissection and digital exploration are performed to ensure that there are no obstructions or adhesions and to create a safe pathway for the tube. Digital exploration helps confirm that the tube enters the pleural space properly and safely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When inserting an intercostal drainage tube, it is crucial to place the tube along the upper border of the lower rib to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle that runs along the lower border of the upper rib.

questions.text: What is the age group distribution for vulval cancer? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 55-85 years

 

55-85 years: Correct. The majority of vulval cancer cases are diagnosed in women aged 55 to 85 years. The average age of diagnosis is between 60 and 65 years.

 

Vulval cancer primarily affects older women, and its age distribution is as follows:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Not age specific: Incorrect. Vulval cancer is not "not age specific"; it is specifically associated with an older age group.

 

Option B. 35-55 years: Incorrect. Although vulval cancer can occur in younger women, the majority of cases are diagnosed in the older age group, typically between 55 and 85 years.

 

Option D. Both of the above: Incorrect. The age distribution for vulval cancer does not cover both age groups mentioned (35-55 years and 55-85 years) equally. The more accurate distribution is predominantly in the 55-85 years range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval cancer predominantly affects women aged 55 to 85 years, with the average diagnosis occurring between 60 and 65 years.

 

Ref: Page no 333, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Two distinct patient cohorts at AIIMS New Delhi are subjected to different treatments to monitor their post-treatment blood pressure levels. The groups do not have overlapping members. Which statistical test would best suit the analysis of the blood pressure differences between the two groups? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unpaired t test

 

  • In the provided situation, two distinct groups are under comparison, and therefore, the appropriate statistical analysis would involve employing a Student's t-test or an unpaired t-test.
  • T tests are used if 2 groups are being compared. If the same group is compared before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paired t test: Used when comparing the same group before and after an intervention, not suitable for independent groups.

 

Option C. ANOVA: Used for comparing means among three or more groups.

 

Option D. Chi-square test: Used for categorical data, not for comparing means of continuous data.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 2 to 4% Cocaine

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden-onset vision changes in his right eye after accidentally rubbing his eye with his hands following gardening work. He reports using eye drops found at home but is unsure of the contents. On examination, his right pupil is dilated and does not react to light or accommodation, while the left pupil is normal. The patient is otherwise neurologically intact. The ophthalmologist decides to perform pharmacologic testing to determine the underlying cause of the pupillary abnormality. Which test is most appropriate to differentiate the cause of the fixed dilated pupil?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1% Pilocarpine

 

Explanation:

 

1% Pilocarpine is used to differentiate between neurologic causes of mydriasis, such as oculomotor nerve palsy, and mydriasis due to anticholinergic agents. In neurologic mydriasis (e.g., oculomotor nerve palsy), the pupil will constrict in response to Pilocarpine due to intact cholinergic receptors. In contrast, mydriasis caused by anticholinergic exposure, such as accidental exposure to plant alkaloids or medications like atropine, will not respond because the muscarinic receptors are blocked.

 

Additional Details:

 

Neurologic mydriasis responds to Pilocarpine, indicating intact but dysfunctional nerve input.

 

Anticholinergic mydriasis does not respond due to receptor blockade, differentiating it from other causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epinephrine : Epinephrine is not used to differentiate fixed dilated pupils but rather to induce dilation for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes.

 

Option C. 2 to 4% Cocaine: Cocaine tests for Horner’s syndrome by blocking norepinephrine reuptake, leading to dilation of a normal pupil but not a Horner’s pupil due to sympathetic disruption.

 

Option D. 0.5% Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is also used in Horner’s syndrome to reverse anisocoria by dilating the affected pupil. It does not differentiate causes of fixed dilation related to neurologic or anticholinergic mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1% Pilocarpine is used to identify the neurologic origin of mydriasis, such as oculomotor nerve palsy, by causing pupil constriction. In contrast, anticholinergic mydriasis will not respond, indicating receptor blockade.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Pneumomediastinum

 

Hamman sign, also known as Hamman's mediastinal crunch, is a crunching, rasping sound, synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium in cases of pneumomediastinum. This sign is caused by air in the mediastinum, which is the central compartment of the thoracic cavity. The presence of air in this area leads to a characteristic sound as the heart beats, which can be heard on auscultation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, usually due to gastrointestinal perforation. Clinical signs include guarding, rigidity, and air under the diaphragm visible on imaging. Hamman sign is not associated with pneumoperitoneum.

 

Option B. Pneumopericardium: This condition involves air within the pericardial cavity surrounding the heart. While it can cause similar auscultatory findings, it does not specifically present with Hamman sign.

 

Option D. Hydropneumothorax: This condition involves both air and fluid in the pleural space. A significant clinical finding here is straight-line dullness on percussion, not Hamman sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hamman sign, or Hamman's crunch, is a specific clinical sign heard in cases of pneumomediastinum, characterized by a crunching sound synchronous with the heartbeat due to the presence of air in the mediastinum.

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This is due to inhibition of_____ by aspirin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboxane Synthesis

 

Thromboxane A2 is a substance that promotes platelet aggregation and also causes vasoconstriction. Aspirin inhibits the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is crucial for the synthesis of thromboxane A2. By inhibiting thromboxane synthesis, aspirin reduces platelet aggregation, which can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, manifesting as occult blood in the stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phospholipase A2: This enzyme is involved in the initial step of arachidonic acid release from cell membranes, but it is not directly inhibited by aspirin. The effect of aspirin is more downstream in the arachidonic acid pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Phospholipase C is involved in intracellular signaling but is not inhibited by aspirin. It does not play a direct role in the mechanism by which aspirin may cause occult blood in the stool.

 

Option D. Phospholipase D: Similar to Phospholipase C, Phospholipase D is not inhibited by aspirin and is not involved in the mechanism leading to gastrointestinal bleeding from aspirin use.

 

Therefore, in this patient, the occult blood in the stool is most likely due to the inhibition of thromboxane synthesis by aspirin, making option B the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin inhibits thromboxane synthesis by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to reduced platelet aggregation and an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient's symptoms? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right Ventricle

 

The patient’s presentation is characteristic of right ventricular failure, often secondary to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in chronic smokers.

 

Key clinical features include:

 

  • Shortness of breath: A common symptom in both left and right heart failure but is notably worsened by right heart failure due to fluid overload.
  • Bilateral pitting pedal edema: Indicates fluid retention, a hallmark of right ventricular failure.
  • Abdominal distension: Often due to ascites, which is related to increased venous pressure.
  • Elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP): Reflects increased central venous pressure due to right heart dysfunction.
  • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver): Due to congestion of blood in the liver secondary to increased venous pressure.

 

Right ventricular failure results from the right ventricle's inability to pump blood effectively to the lungs, leading to a backup of blood in the systemic venous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: Left ventricular failure primarily causes pulmonary congestion and edema due to the backflow of blood into the lungs. Symptoms like shortness of breath would predominate without the systemic venous congestion (e.g., pedal edema, elevated JVP, hepatomegaly) seen in right ventricular failure.

 

Option C. Aorta: An aortic abnormality would not directly cause the combination of symptoms described. Issues with the aorta generally result in systemic hypertension, aortic aneurysm, or dissection, which have different clinical presentations.

 

Option D. Mitral Valve: Mitral valve disease, particularly mitral stenosis or regurgitation, primarily affects the left atrium and ventricle, leading to pulmonary congestion and symptoms more indicative of left heart failure rather than the systemic congestion seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right ventricular failure is characterized by systemic venous congestion, which manifests as elevated jugular venous pressure, pitting pedal edema, hepatomegaly, and abdominal distension. This condition is often seen in chronic smokers due to the impact of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on the heart.

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks

questions.text: A nurse got accidental prick from the HIV infected needle. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this nurse? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) involves a series of steps to reduce the risk of HIV infection after potential exposure, such as a needlestick injury.

 

  1. Washing the Wound: Immediately after exposure, the wound should be washed thoroughly with soap and water. This helps to reduce the risk of infection.
  2. Baseline Viral Markers: Blood samples should be taken from the exposed individual to measure baseline viral markers. This provides a reference point to determine if the infection was acquired.
  3. Triple Drug Therapy: PEP should be initiated within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as soon as possible. The recommended regimen includes a combination of three antiretroviral drugs:
    • Tenofovir
    • Lamivudine (or Emtricitabine)
    • A boosted protease inhibitor (such as lopinavir/ritonavir)

 

Zidovudine monotherapy is not recommended. Combination therapy is more effective in preventing seroconversion.

 

  1. Follow-Up Testing: Follow-up viral markers should be measured at 6 weeks post-exposure to check for HIV infection. Additional testing may also be done at 3 months and 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Washing hands with soap and water is advised: This is correct. Washing the wound with soap and water immediately after exposure is a crucial first step.

 

Option C. Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick: This is correct. Establishing baseline viral markers at the time of exposure is essential for monitoring potential seroconversion.

 

Option D. Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks: This is correct. Follow-up testing at 6 weeks is recommended to detect any early seroconversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POST EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS

 

  • Treatment should be started within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as early as possible
  • At first the wound is washed with soap and water.
  • Secondly before initiating drug therapy blood samples are taken to measure the baseline viral markers
  • Then, triple drug therapy is given which includes Tenofovir, Lamivudine and a boosted protease inhibitor for 28 days.
  • After 6 weeks again viral markers are measured to check for the infection.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/872

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary oedema
  2. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin can cause headache
  4. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A and C

 

Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which is protective for the gastric mucosa. It is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

A. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary edema: Morphine can be used in the acute management of pulmonary edema, particularly when it's due to heart failure. It reduces preload and afterload on the heart and can alleviate the associated anxiety and discomfort. However, its use has become less common due to concerns about potential side effects, including respiratory depression.

 

C. Indomethacin can cause headache: This is true. While Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat pain, inflammation, and fever, one of its side effects can be headache.

 

Other options:

 

B. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic: Pethidine (Meperidine) is generally not recommended for biliary colic because it can cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi, potentially worsening pain in biliary coli due to its anticholinergic property.

 

D. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease: This is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which protects the gastric mucosa. Aspirin is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine can be used for the treatment of pulmonary edema, and indomethacin can cause headaches.
  • Aspirin is not used for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and can actually worsen it. While opioids can be used for biliary colic, their use is not without complications, and not all opioids are appropriate for this condition.

choices.text: Peutz Jegher syndrome
Villous adenoma
Juvenile polyp

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was admitted to the hospital with a history of prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. The histopathological image of the mass is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Juvenile Polyp

 

The clinical features and the histopathological image showing characteristic cystically dilated crypts and glands are suggestive of a juvenile polyp.

 

  • Juvenile (retention) polyps are mucosal epithelial and lamina propria malformations. These can be sporadic or syndromic, but their morphology is often indistinguishable. The vast majority of juvenile polyps are found in children under the age of five. When found in adults, polyps with the same morphology are sometimes referred to as inflammatory polyps. The majority of juvenile polyps are in the rectum and cause painless rectal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Puetz Jegher syndrome: Puetz Jegher syndrome is a rare autosomal dominant syndrome that manifests as multiple GI hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation at the age of 11 years.

 

 

 

Option B. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas are neoplastic and present with a different histopathological pattern of finger-like or villous projections.

 

  • They are usually found in older adults and are not typically associated with painless rectal bleeding in children.

 

Option D. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that can range from small polyps to large sessile lesions.

 

  • They do not exhibit the cystically dilated glands seen in juvenile polyps and are also more common in older adults.

 

Note - Adenomas are intraepithelial neoplasms that range in size from small polyps to large sessile lesions. There is no preference for either gender, and both are present in nearly 50% of adults living in the Western world by age 50. Adenomas can be classified as tubular, tubulovillous, or villous based on their architecture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile polyps are the most common type of rectal polyps in children under five, characterized by cystically dilated crypts and glands, and often present with painless rectal bleeding.

questions.text: Ring sequestrum is associated with which of the following? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) External pin fixator

 

  • A sequestrum is infected dead bone formed as a squealae of chronic osteomyelitis.
  • Ring sequestrum is a low grade chronic osteomyelitis following pintract infection producing an unusual sequestrum surrounded by radiolucent area, another circle of sclerotic bone.
  • Improper aseptic technique of skeletal pin traction, thermal necrosis, prolonged duration, poor pin tract care and comorbid conditions can lead to this complications and presents with skin discharge, pin loosening and osteomyelitis.
  • Thorough surgical debridement, sequestrectomy and saucerisation with appropriate antibiotics and dead space management will successfully treat it.

 

 

TYPES OF SEQUESTRUMS

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation exposure. The response of bone to the trauma of radiation is inflammation. This is seen radiographically as an increase in sclerosis. Irradiated bone has less ability to remodel. Radiation therapy (as well as bisphosphonate therapy) can be considered as macrotrauma that lower the threshold of the ability for bone to repair. Adding in microtrauma events such as dental extraction, denture irritation, break in mucosal protection from traumatic ulceration may lead to exceeding the bone’s capacity to remodel, resulting in necrosis and sequestra formation. When the sequestrum is superficial, bone exposure may occur. When the sequestrum is deeper within the bone, radiographic signs may be the only diagnostic features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ring sequestrum is most commonly caused due to external pin fixators, mainly Steinmann pins.

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus

questions.text: A 10-day-old newborn is brought to the paediatric clinic with complaints of redness and discharge from both eyes that began five days after birth. The parents report that the discharge has been persistent, and the baby's eyes are often stuck shut, especially in the mornings. The infant was delivered vaginally without complications, and the mother did not have any known infections during pregnancy. On examination, there is significant conjunctival injection, bilateral eye discharge, and mild swelling of the eyelids. The physician suspects ophthalmia neonatorum and considers the most likely causative organism. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition in developed countries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Chlamydia trachomatis

 

Explanation:

 

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries. This type of neonatal conjunctivitis typically presents 5-14 days after birth with symptoms of eye redness, discharge, and mild eyelid swelling. The infection is usually acquired during vaginal delivery from an infected mother, even if she is asymptomatic. Chlamydia conjunctivitis requires prompt antibiotic treatment, typically with oral erythromycin, to prevent complications such as pneumonia or blindness. Early recognition and appropriate management are essential for preventing further morbidity associated with this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes simplex virus: Although HSV can cause neonatal conjunctivitis, it is less common and typically presents with more severe symptoms, including vesicular lesions around the eyes, keratitis, and potential corneal involvement, often within the first week of life.

 

Option B. Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a less common but severe cause of ophthalmia neonatorum, usually presenting within 2-5 days after birth with a rapidly progressing purulent discharge, eyelid swelling, and potential corneal damage, requiring immediate systemic antibiotic therapy.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause neonatal conjunctivitis, but it is generally a milder form with variable onset and is not the most common cause in developed countries. It often presents with less severe discharge and inflammation compared to Chlamydia or Neisseria infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of ophthalmia neonatorum in developed countries, typically presenting 5-14 days after birth with red eyes and discharge. This condition is transmitted during vaginal delivery and requires prompt antibiotic treatment to prevent complications such as pneumonia and blindness.

questions.text: Most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PDA

 

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ASD: ASD is the common congenital heart disease in down syndrome

 

Option B. VSD: VSD is the common congenital heart disease in infant of diabetic mother

 

Option D. PS: PS (pulmonary stenosis) is the common congenital heart disease in noonan and Alagille syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), followed by Pulmonary Stenosis (PS).

questions.text: Identify the type of injury given in the image below:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contusion

 

The image above shows a contusion.

 

  • A contusion, or bruise, is caused by a direct blow to the body that can cause damage to the surface of the skin and to deeper tissues as well depending on the severity of the blow.
  • It causes rupture of capillaries of the skin leading to the bruise

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abrasion: Abrasion is a superficial injury where the skin is scraped off, usually due to friction against a rough surface. It does not typically involve deep tissue damage or significant bruising.

 

Option C. Laceration: A laceration is a tear or a jagged wound caused by blunt trauma. It usually has irregular margins and can vary in depth and severity.

 

Option D. Stab wound: A stab wound is a penetrating injury caused by a sharp object such as a knife. It is characterized by a small entry point and can vary greatly in depth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contusions, also known as bruises, are caused by blunt trauma that ruptures capillaries beneath the skin, leading to discoloration. They differ from abrasions, lacerations, and stab wounds in their mechanism of injury and appearance.

questions.text: What is the gauge size of the cannula utilized as given in the picture below: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 18


The image shows a cannula with a green hub, which is typically used to indicate an 18 gauge (18G) IV cannula. Gauge sizes in cannulas correlate with their diameter and flow rate; the color coding helps quickly identify the size. The 18G cannula is commonly used in medical settings for adult patients needing moderate to large volume infusions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 14: Incorrect, as 14G cannulas are typically orange and are used for large volume rapid infusions, often in trauma settings.

 

Option B. 16: Incorrect, as 16G cannulas typically have a grey hub, and are also used for large volume infusions, but with slightly less flow capacity than the 14G.

 

Option D. 20: Incorrect, as 20G cannulas are generally pink and are used for smaller volume infusions, suitable for children or when less fluid is needed.

 

Educational Objective:


Recognize the color coding of IV cannulas to identify their gauge sizes, understanding that the color green typically indicates an 18 gauge cannula suitable for moderate to large volume infusions in adults.

questions.text: You are posted as a medical officer in a rural Primary Health Centre (PHC) for your rural internship. As part of your duties, you are required to oversee and understand the roles and responsibilities of ASHA working in your region. Which of the following tasks is NOT traditionally a responsibility of the ASHA worker? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria slide preparation

 

  • ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) workers play a crucial role in community health, especially in rural areas of India.
  • Their responsibilities are extensive but focused primarily on preventive and promotive healthcare. But not the malaria slides preparation.
  • Preparation of malaria slides is the responsibility of health worker male.

 

Other 3 options are ASHA responsibilities

 

Educational Objective:

 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

 

  • Create awareness on health and its social determinants and mobilize the community towards local health planning and increased utilization and accountability of the existing health services
  • Promote good health practices and provide a minimum package of curative care as appropriate and feasible and make timely referrals
  • Provide information on determinants of health, on existing health services and the need for timely utilization of services
  • Counsel women on aspects of reproductive and child health
  • Mobilize the community and facilitate them in accessing health and health related services provided by the government
  • Act as a depot holder for essential provisions like ORS, IFA tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills & condoms
  • Provide primary medical care and act as DOTS provider
  • Help develop a comprehensive village health plan
  • Arrange escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment/ admission to nearest health facility
  • Be a part of JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) and help reduce MMR

 

Additional Information

 

Proposed population norm: 2 ASHA worker per 1000 population

 

ASHA is expected to act as,

 

  • Interface between: Community and Health care system
  • Bridge between: ANM and village
  • Accountable to: Panchayat

 

Selection criteria of ASHA:

 

  • Woman resident of local community
  • Preferably 25 – 45 years age
  • Literate with formal education up to 10th class (Relaxable for Tribal areas)

 

Indicators for Monitoring and Evaluation of ASHA’s Work

 

  • Process indicators:
    • No. of ASHAs selected
    • No. of ASHAs trained
    • % ASHAs attending review meeting after 1 year
  • Outcome indicators:
    • % newborns weighed and families counseled
    • % deliveries with skilled assistance
    • % institutional deliveries
    • % JSY claims made to ASHA
    • Completed immunized 12-23 months age group
    • % unmet need in BPL
    • % fever cases received chloroquine within 1 weeks in endemic area
  • Impact indicators:
    • Infant mortality rate (IMR)
    • Child malnutrition rates
    • No. of cases of TB/Leprosy detected as compared to last year.

questions.text: Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes?  (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-B, 3-D, 4-C

 

Explanation:

 

  • MRKH syndrome (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser): This syndrome has a karyotype of 46XX.
  • Swyer Syndrome: This condition is characterized by 46XY karyotype.
  • Turner Syndrome: This is due to monosomy X, having a karyotype of 45XO.
  • Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: This condition occurs in individuals with a karyotype of 46XY, where there is a complete androgen insensitivity, resulting in a phenotypically female appearance despite having male (XY) chromosomes.

 

Matching:

 

  1. MRKH: 46XX
  2. Swyer Syndrome: 46XY
  3. Turner Syndrome: 45XO
  4. Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: 46XY

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the karyotypes associated with different syndromes helps in diagnosing and managing these conditions effectively. MRKH is associated with 46XX, Swyer syndrome with 46XY, Turner syndrome with 45XO, and Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome with 46XY.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 446,447
